The tanh of x is (e^x - e^(-x)) / (e^x + e^(-x)), right? But maybe there's a simpler way to compute it using numpy. Oh wait, numpy has a built-in tanh function! So instead of calculating it manually, I can just use np.tanh(x). That would be the most straightforward way.

Wait, the problem says to return the result, so in the function self.function(x), the return statement should be np.tanh(x). Let me check the derivative part. Hmm, are there any other possible ways? Like, maybe using the exponential form? But using np.tanh is more efficient and accurate.
